results.title: Techno
results.brief_description: Presented in a magazine-style fomat, with excellent pupil notes, “Techno” aims to stimulate 11-14 years olds in the areas of design and technology. Using a problem-solving approach, with “real world” examples, the programs give necessary background information and guidance on how to solve these. Curriculum areas covered by these programs include graphic communication, woodcraft, textiles, materials such as plastic and metal, and basic engineering concepts.

results.title: Teamwork: past and present
results.creator_credit: Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This first cell-animated film produced by the NFB traces the development of the master/worker relationships through successive eras of history. Stone engravings record a complete absence of cooperation between the Egyptian ruler and his slaves but, beginning with the Greeks and Romans, there was a gradual change towards recognition of the labourer. With the growth of factories, the trend received a setback, but reasserted itself through the expediencies of World War II, which saw the formation of the first Labour Management Production Committee (LMPC) in Britain. In post-war Canada the film shows LMPCs well implanted in industrial life, with the Industrial Production Cooperation Board giving official government recognition. Animation by Colin Low.

results.title: Teeth are to keep
results.creator_credit: Dino Rigolo, Jim MacKay, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A gaily colored cartoon with a cheerful little story to drive home the importance of the four essentials of tooth care. The film shows the function of various teeth and the foods that will help to keep them healthy. Brushing teeth after every meal is stressed, as well as yearly visits to the dentist. Animation reveals how a tooth decays.

results.title: Teamwork
results.brief_description: Six means by which cooperation can be achieved are illustrated by a group of high school students planning a dance. Leadership, bargaining, trickery, exploitation, compromise, democratic cooperation are shown as students complete arrangements. Introduction and summary show out-of-school examples of same methods.

results.title: Teaching a language structure by the Australian situational method. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Ian Hart, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Part 2 shows excerpts from the teaching of the interrogative and negative patterns, and the long and short answer forms of the verb “to have”. It again lays emphasis on the lesson steps of the situational method, and has a final sequence showing students at work in a language laboratory.

results.title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II: the secret of the ooze (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Michael Pressman, David Chan, Kim Dawson, Thomas K. Gray, Gary Propper and Golden Harvest
results.brief_description: The four hip superheroes Raphael, Leonardo, Michaelangelo and Donatello continue their bodacious adventures as they find a new sewer home and with the help of curvaceous TV reporter April O’Neil, Professor Jordon and Keno, the pizza delivery boy they battle the Foot gang and other mutant villains to discover their origins, to save New York and to keep the mutant-causing green ooze from falling into evil hands.

results.title: Teenage crises: fateful choices
results.creator_credit: Linda Atkinson, Nick Doob and Human Relations Media
results.brief_description: This hard-hitting documentary addresses many of the significant problems encountered by today’s youth: addiction, violence, pregnancy, AIDS and depression/suicide. “Teenage crises” attempts to shake up the notion of teen invincibility by talking to young people who have come through hard times, including Olympic gold medal swimmer Nelson Deibel, an ex-drug addict. Stresses the importance of finding positive role models and being secure enough to make the right choices.

results.title: Tea with Mussolini
results.creator_credit: Franco Zeffirelli, Clive Parsons, Giovanella Zannoni, Riccardo Tozzi, Cattleya, Cineritmo, G2, Medusa Film and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Loosely based on his childhood, Zeffirelli weaves this enchanting tale with a gentle, loving hand. It is the story of a diverse group of cultured ladies, living in Florence in 1934, who meet for tea each afternoon. The group includes Lady Random (Maggie Smith), widow of the British ambassador to Italy, Arabella (Judy Dench) an artist and singer, Georgie (Lily Tomlin), an exuberant American archaeologist, and the brash and uninhibited Elsa (Cher). One of the ladies, Mary (Joan Plowright), becomes a surrogate mother to a young boy, Luca, and he is soon virtually adopted and brought up by the group. As Luca grows to become a man, the shifting political climate begins to have a devastating impact on the rarified world in which the ladies exist, and they must come to terms not only with their own mortality but also the inescapable passage of time.

results.title: Australian Capital Territory
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Holiday”.
Australia’s capital city, although relatively young, offers a range of cultural, historical and natural attractions. Enjoy panoramic views of Canberra from a hot air balloon, a ride into Snowy River country, a 4WD adventure through the ACT or a coach tour to the War Memorial, the National Film and Sound Archive, Parliament House or the National Art Gallery.
